description: In Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) from April 8, "police warn people to be cautious" about "corona-linked fraud" and to "consult others when encountering such suspicious situations". For example, there had been cases of victims who "failed to receive surgical masks and other sanitation products they ordered online" and of "suspicious emails and phone calls offering corporate bonds" to develop corona cures.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: On May 13, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) issued an announcement to its citizens that suspicious phone calls, emails and short messages (SMS), social networking services (SNS), websites, etc. regarding new coronavirus infectious diseases and special fixed benefit have been confirmed. "Please be careful of unfamiliar phone calls, e-mails, and websites so that you will not fall victim to crimes caused by these new coronavirus infections."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: On June 18. the Okayama Prefecture is asking all citizens of the prefecture to act from the standpoint of the other person based on the correct information announced by the national government and local governments. "In relation to the new coronavirus infection, slanderous slander against infected persons, their families, persons involved in medical institutions, persons in specific countries, and unsubstantiated and discriminatory writings on SNS etc. are seen. Such acts are human rights violations and are not permissible."

description: On August 25, 2020, the draft Ordinance on Cluster Measures for Preventing the Spread of New Coronavirus Infection in Tottori Prefecture was approved after a revised decision at the extraordinary session in August 2 of the Tottori Prefectural Assembly (Japan). The ordinance prohibits slander and unfair discriminatory behavior regarding new-type coronavirus infections.

"Due to the outbreak of this infection, we decided to temporarily close the prefectural schools and Nishi Senboku High School in Akita City, Oga City, Katagami City, and Nanaki Area from today until April 26." "Prefectural schools have resumed classes on April 6th, except in some areas, but we will stop these schools for the time being to prevent the spread of infection. description: On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The revised end date of SoE which announced on May 14 was May 31. However, since the new infection cases decreased radically, Fukui Prefecture Government decides to declare the end of SoE on May 26 when is 5 days earlier than the revised end of the date.

description: On April 13, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) declared a state of warning against COVID-19. However, the national government of Japan declared a state of emergency on the country on April 16.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo declared that "the virus has been spreading in six prefectures  Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, and Kyoto  to the same extent as in the seven prefectures where the state of emergency originally applied. Those seven are Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka." Accordingly, the "13 prefectures have now been designated as "special alert prefectures" where it is necessary to promote efforts to prevent the spread of infections."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Hokkaido Prefectural Government announces a state of emergency "to prevent the further spread of COVID-19" from April 17 to May 31.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, "expanded [...] the state of emergency beyond seven prefectures to the entire nation in an attempt to prevent the new coronavirus from spreading further and straining the health care system."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On April 17, 2020, the town major of Taketomi (Ishigaki, Yaeyama Islands, Okinawa) Nishiomasu Kojun declared the island's own state of emergency in order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo announced that the Government of Japan "intend[s] to request the Expert Meeting to assess the [emergency] situation" on May 14. The Government of Japan will "ask the Expert Meeting to conduct detailed analyses on the trend of new cases in each area and the degree of pressure on medical treatment structures."
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, "extended a nationwide state of emergency to May 31, saying the new coronavirus infection rate had yet to drop enough to justify ending measures aimed at slowing the outbreak."
 UPDATE: Japan has extended the state of emergency to May 31, 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: The original end of the prefectural state of emergency was May 6, and it has been extended to May 31. UPDATE: The original end of the prefectural state of emergency was May 6, and it has been extended to May 31.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 6, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, announced that "[l]ifting state of emergency to be reviewed on a weekly basis." "Having extended its nationwide state of emergency by a month, the government now says it will consider week by week whether to lift it earlier and offered May 21 as a new date, depending on infection rates."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Following the national government on May 14, the Shimane Prefectural Government (Japan) has lifted the state of emergency and will relax restrictions.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As of May 14, the state of emergency no longer applies to Okayama Prefecture (Japan). Since there are still prefectures that are under special security, the governor decided that it would be best to maintain the policies that we have kept up until now.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 14, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) was released from the Emergency Declaration following the national government.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Municipal Government

description: On July 31, 2020, the Governor of Okinawa Prefecture in Japan, Denny Tamaki, "declared a state of emergency [...] for the second time after warning that COVID-19 infections in the southernmost prefecture are spreading 'at an explosive pace.'" The declaration period is valid from August 1, 2020 to August 15, 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 28, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) announced the decision to extend the declaration of a state of emergency until September 5, 2020. UPDATE: On August 28, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) announced the decision to extend the declaration of a state of emergency until September 5, 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 13, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) announced the decision to extend the declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020. UPDATE: Extended until August 29
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Aichi (Japan) "declared its own state of emergency at an anti-coronavirus meeting." "The state of emergency will continue for 19 days" until August 24, 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On January 31, 2020, at the Second Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that Japan "will deny entry of individuals who are infected by the virus in accordance with the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act. Furthermore, it is also necessary to strengthen immigration controls to respond to the cases in which infection has not been confirmed. Based on the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus with or without symptoms, [the Government] must further improve the effectiveness of border controls."
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan "designated the infectious disease related to the novel coronavirus a Designated Infectious Disease under the Act on the Prevention of Infectious Diseases and Medical Care for Patients with Infectious Diseases" on February 28, 2020, planned its enforcement on February 7, 2020, but brought it forward to February 1, 2020. The announcement took place on January 31, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description: At a press conference on June 23, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "it has been decided to operate special flights from Japan to Viet Nam over the three-day period on June 25, 26, and 27 arranged by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Viet Nam. Through these flights, it is planned for about 440 Japanese residents and businesspeople to travel to Viet Nam. They will be the first flights from Japan to Viet Nam since the agreement to relax restrictions partially and gradually on mutual travel between our countries. For this travel, the people who go to Viet Nam will enter the country in accordance with Viet Nams designated process of measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Also, among the travelers, businesspeople who will return to Japan after a relatively short time are expected to enter Japan in accordance with the trial measures for entry based on the decision made last week on June 18 by the National Security Council (NSC) and the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters. Specifically, on the condition that they comply with additional infection control measures, it is expected that measures will apply to them that enable limited business activities during the 14-day waiting period, such as waiting at home."
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided that "if it is confirmed that a person is infected at a medical institution, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases should  arrange proper inspection and retrace the close contacts of the infected person."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided to "implement national border control measures, such as checking the health status of people entering the country from areas with a high risk of infection, with tools such as thermographies at quarantine stations."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[t]aking into consideration the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus despite exhibiting no symptoms, it is necessary for us to phase up our responses including quarantine measures. [...] We will introduce a measure, aimed at all people entering Japan with any history of travelling to Wuhan or related areas, that checks their contact information while in Japan and follows up on their health status, regardless of whether or not they have exhibited any symptoms."
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Fukuoka Prefecture advises from February 25 that residents with "cold symptoms or high fever" (37.5 degrees Celsius or more) and/or continual "excessive fatigue or difficulty with breathing" for more than four days 
 should phone a medical centre for consultation. On the other hand, "elderly people and others who have underlying diseases" should phone if these symptoms continue for two days.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Saga Prefecture set up a 24/7 phone line from March 1 "exclusively for foreign residents to help them speak to the consultation centers in 18 languages" regarding coronavirus symptoms. The provided languages are English, Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese, Malay, Nepalese, Tagalog, Bahasa Indonesian, Portuguese, French, Spanish, Russian, Italian, German, Thai, Burmese, Khmer and Mongolian.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Kagoshima Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Disease Control Headquarters requests from March 27 for residents to call the Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts advice line in the event of a long term fever, symptoms of tiredness, suffocating or difficulty in breathing.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of health monitoring measures on its village ferries. Body temperature and health conditions of crew members will be checked every day. Before boarding the ferry, the temperature of passengers will be taken. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On April 7, 2020, the Welfare Department of Tarama Island and Tarama Clinic asked residents to contact the clinic "if you have been out of Okinawa or outside the prefecture or if your relatives have been visiting you from Okinawa main island or from outside Okinawa prefecture after March 20." "Regarding homecoming high school children due to the prefectural extension of public high school closure, please measure the temperature twice daily and monitor cough, runny nose, sore throat." [loose translation from Japanese]
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Naha Airport in Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) has voluntary installed thermography devices to measure the body temperature of passing customers and has started to distribute leaflets with health recommendations to those exceeding the standard value on April 9, 2020. No access restrictions are being performed.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of May 22, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) is mandating its citizens to contact a consultation center if any of their symptoms continue for four days or longer. "If you feel that your symptoms are strong, please consult immediately, as the symptoms vary with the individual. This also applies to those who are taking antipyretics.) We ask that individuals with symptoms take leave from work or school and refrain from going out."
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
Japan (Tokyo), on June 05, 2020, "in order to safely use the metropolitan facilities visited by many users, [the Tokyo Metropolitan Government] build a new 'Tokyo version of new corona watching service' from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of new coronavirus infection".
"This service is a mechanism that promptly notifies the user of infection information based on the visit history of the facility when a new coronavirus infectious disease cluster occurs in a metropolitan facility."
Targeted facilities include Metropolitan cultural facilities, sports facilities, gardens/zoos, libraries, etc. (will be expanded in the future).
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On June 19, the Saga prefecture (Japan) announced that it will be using the mew coronavirus contact confirmation application (COCOA), developed to contribute to extended prevention of new coronavirus infectious disease in Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 22, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "temporarily stop[ep] the app from issuing any alerts," as it "erroneously accepts reference numbers not issued by the Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry." "To prevent confusion, officials have halted the issuance of personal numbers. This means the app's contact-notification function will remain out of service. Officials say they plan to fix the flaw as soon as possible." UPDATE: Bugs in the app have "forced the ministry to temporarily stop the app from issuing any alerts."

The business will start on June 27, 2020.

description: From July 15, Fukuoka Prefecture encourages residents to use COCOA, "a contract-tracing application developed to prevent the spread" of COVID-19.

description: On July 22, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) established a branch office of the Travelers Access Center Okinawa (TACO) at Miyako Airport. The office will provide health consultations for visitors. If fever is confirmed, it will be possible, with the consent of the patient, to transfer with a dedicated car from the airport to Miyako Hospital in order to conduct a PCR test.

description: On July 24, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) urges its citizens to visit the consultation center if they had visited the Koyama Chinese Cuisine in an effort to conduct contact tracing with novel coronavirus cases.

description: As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will utilize more digital technologies to more efficiently detect and track cases.

description: On August 3, the Tottori Municipal Public Health Center (Japan) announced the planned implementation of the examination for the faculty members of Tottori City Higashi Junior High School and all the school students in relation to the 15th case positive in the prefecture (12th case of the Tottori City Public Health Center).
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On August 5, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) launched a coronavirus countermeasure security system. 

"If a person who is positive for the new coronavirus is found among the participants of a large-scale event held in Tottori Prefecture, a service will be sent from the prefecture to alert the recipients to the email address registered at the venue."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that it "plans to ask elderly facilities to simulate a coronavirus outbreak by the end of August, as part of its resurgence response." "Staff at the facilities will also be asked to check stock levels of sanitary goods such as disinfectant and face masks and how they are checking the health of the staff. With the steps, the ministry aims to prevent an infection cluster among elderly people with a higher risk of developing serious conditions." "Facilities will have to report to the ministry by early September on whether they have taken the steps. Facilities required to carry out such simulations are special elderly nursing homes, nursing care facilities, homes for the elderly with care services and other establishments where many old people live together."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As of August 14, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will begin using its new "Hiroshima Corona News QR" service that uses QR codes to inform citizens that they may have contacted an infected person and supports them to have a PCR test to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infections.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 29 January 2020, Osaka Prefecture, Japan, established a telephone consultation service for citizens of the prefecture. The consultation service is available everyday, including weekends and public holidays from 9:00AM to 6:00PM.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "[e]ven for those individuals who have tested negative, [the Government is] thoroughly monitoring health condition of each and every person under appropriate controls, by stationing doctors at all accommodation facilities on a round-the-clock basis, [and] also providing push-mode support for daily living essentials, including face masks, sanitizers, thermometers, and other daily items, to those privately-owned accommodations and government facilities who have pledged their cooperation."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 5, 2020, at the Fifth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government is "working on developing systems to enable private testing institutions to conduct screenings that the National Institute of Infectious Diseases and Public Health Institutes have been conducting."

description:
On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. 

From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00. UPDATE: On 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Returnee/ Contact Consultation Centre were extended.

description: "The Government of Japan decided to provide China with 4,800 safety goggles and 5,200 isolation suits, which are part of the equipment stockpiled by Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and financed by Japans contribution, as in-kind contribution from the Government of Japan. This in-kind contribution was transported to Wuhan by the chartered flight which left Japan on Wednesday, February 6, and handed over to the Chinese side at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport on Thursday, February 7."

The call center is open from 9 a.m.-9 p.m., seven days a week, including holidays."

description: At the end of February 2020, Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) "published a webpage titled, "For Safe Travels in Japan: Guide for when you are feeling ill," which allows users to find medical professionals in their area that speak English, Chinese, and Korean, plus other languages (Polish, French, German) that are less available. It also includes a brief guide for how to use travel medical insurance and typical Japanese hospital procedures. The tourism site also launched the Bebot x JNTO chatbot, which gives users information on COVID-19, restrictions on travel from China, travel insurance, as well as the option to "speak to human.""

description: On February 26, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture "has established a help desk for COVID-19 as well as the countermeasures for virus infection." The service is available in English, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish, Vietnamese and Thai."

description: According to the Ministry of Justice of Japan (MOJ), inmates of "seven prisons in Aomori, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Yamaguchi and Kochi prefecture" have been sewing "cloth face masks" since March 2020. "Having received orders from private-sector companies, these prisons now have the combined capacity to sew some 66,000 such masks a month. They also started preparations to make medical gowns that are in short supply as well."

description: In Sendai, to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, BCG vaccination in March is, as a general rule, carried out only for children who are one year old by the beginning of April and have not been vaccinated. If the vaccination period can be delayed, please inoculate after April. For children who are currently eligible for vaccination, parents will be notified individually.

description: On March 3, Oita Prefecture announced that they have "designated 15 hospitals for outpatient consultations for individuals who have recently returned from overseas or may have come in close contact with a patient", as well as "18 medical institutions designated for infectious diseases" for inpatient treatment.

description: Japan, on Mar. 24 Yamagata government announces increase of tests from Mar. 25: Currently, the number of samples that can be tested per day is 60, but from March 25th, tomorrow, 80 samples can be tested. Furthermore We are preparing to expand to 150 beds if the number of infected people increases.

description: "Japanese Defense Minister Taro Kono issued on Saturday [(March 28, 2020)] an order to dispatch Self-Defense Forces troops as part of his country's efforts to strengthen quarantine steps amid the spread of the new coronavirus. From Saturday, the dispatched troops are engaged in the work to quarantine people arriving at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda and Narita International Airport in Chiba Prefecture, east of Tokyo. They are also supporting the transport of such people to designated facilities. The Defense Ministry dispatched SDF members on a voluntary basis based on a judgment that the current situation represents a case stipulated by the SDF law where the ministry should not wait for a dispatch request from a prefectural governor."

description: Japan will distribute two reusable/washable cloth face masks to each registered household, prioritising the regions with most coronavirus infections. description: On April 11, 2020, Japan has announced measures to "ease the shortages of medical supplies at medical sites". "Regarding medical gowns and face shields, [...] 1 million of each [will] be distributed to the seven prefectures, subject to the degree of scarcity. As for N95 and KN95 masks, [...] 70,000 masks within next week and 700,000 by the end of the month [will be delivered].

At the hotel, 400 rooms are secured for coronavirus patients."

description: Kagoshima Prefecture announced on 24 April that three accommodation facilities have been secured to treat patients with mild cases of COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On April 24 2020 the Minister of Health Labour and Welfare of Japan MHLW approved the domestic production and sales of ventilators for severe patients by Japanese medical equipment manufacturer Nihon Kohden in Japanese <U+65E5><U+672C><U+5149><U+96FB><U+5DE5><U+696D><U+682A><U+5F0F><U+4F1A><U+793E> The company plans to start production soon at its factory in the city of Tomioka Gunma Prefecture Nihon Kohden plans to produce several hundred units a year and begin sales in July To increase domestic production the health ministry has decided to speed up the screening process for companies Nihon Kohden received approval in four days as opposed to the typical four months
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: When a person who is insured by Tottori City National Health Insurance (Japan) is infected with a new coronavirus infection or has a fever etc, the Tottori Prefecture will pay the allowance. Registration began on April 27.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On April 27, 2020, it was announced that a "group of forensic pathologists in Japan says cases have occurred in which bodies of the deceased have been returned to families without undergoing coronavirus tests, despite experts' requests to carry out such checks." "To resolve the problem, forensic researchers in several universities have decided to carry out their own coronavirus tests."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Feb. 27 Fukushima government announces "implementation of infection control measures in facilities for the elderly, etc.".
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: In Tottori prefecture, a new nursing center in Kurayoshi, a nursing center in central Japan, will open on April 27th .
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: At a news conference on April 28, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "Japan will begin providing the anti-flu drug Avigan for free to 38 countries as early as this week for treating patients with the new coronavirus." The Minister added that "over 70 countries, including the 38, have made requests for Avigan to Japan, which has decided to offer a $1 million grant to the United Nations Office for Project Services to buy and distribute the drug, also known as favipiravir, to countries that want it."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: At the beginning of May 2020, the Cabinet Office of Japan told Japanese local governments "to make preparations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus at evacuation centers if natural disasters occur, ahead of the rainy and typhoon seasons." The Cabinet Office prompted "the local governments to set up as many evacuation centers as possible in the event of disasters and consider in advance how to cope with infected evacuees."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description:
On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre were extended (weekdays between 08:30 and 21:00, weekend hours from 10:00 to 16:00). 
   
From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. From Monday to Saturday, the Centre will be open for 24 hours and then the Centre will be closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On May 5, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) announced that "Foreign Ministry's "Tabi-Regi" email-based security information service for Japanese travelers overseas will become available for users of the Line free messaging app. By improving user convenience, the ministry hopes to encourage people making foreign trips to register for the service, ministry officials said. The ministry aims to start the service for Line users in early 2021 at the earliest after a system upgrade."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) approved remdesivir as the first treatment for COVID-19 in Japan, three days after the Japanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Gilead Sciences Inc. submitted the application. The process was accelerated under a special exception clause for pharmaceuticals that are approved by another nation with comparable standards as Japans. The health ministry will initially manage the supply and distribute remdesivir to hospitals with patients with severe symptoms. The drug will be provided for free at first.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On May 9, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (Japan) has "released a stockpile of data on the number of coronavirus tests conducted and the infection rate dating back to late January. Disjointed data on testing, not just in Tokyo but throughout Japan, has been the subject of controversy and scrutiny for months. Researchers say its impossible to understand the true severity of the pandemic without this information."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On May 9, 2020, it was announced that a "group of researchers at the University of Tokyo has started clinical trials of [...] [n]afamostat mesylate, [...] marketed under the brand name Futhan. The tests are being conducted on 160 patients with pneumonia stemming from the coronavirus at the University of Tokyo Hospital and five other medical facilities in Japan. The patients are divided into two groups. One group is administered Futhan and anti-flu drug Avigan. The other is given only Avigan. University of Tokyo Professor Inoue Junichiro is involved in the trials."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Due to the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, it is becoming difficult to obtain masks at stores. The Tottori prefecture (Japan), in cooperation with supermarkets etc., will arrange the purchase.
Mask purchase tickets will be distributed to all units in the prefecture between May 14th, 2020 (May 13th at some post offices) and 20th.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As announced on May 14, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) is accepting consultations from pregnant woman, who are more likely to have anxiety, such as the birth environment changing, with the spread of the new coronavirus.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requested on May 14 for medical institutions to prepare more beds for COVID-19 patients.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Japan, on May 1 Kanagawa Prefecture announced, it will work together with the Prefectural Hospital Organization and Shonan Kamakura General Hospital "to set up a Medical Center for Psychiatric Corona Priority Medical Institution", which will start accepting infected patients with severe mental illness from mid May.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: At a press conference on May 15, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "[i]n regard to Avigan, [...] requests have been received through diplomatic channels for provision of Avigan from close to 80 countries. [...] Avigan has been provided to four countries including Indonesia thus far, and coordination has been completed to provide it to 45 countries. UPDATE: Supply was extended to 80 countries from the originally planned 43 countries.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 18 May 2020, Nara Prefecture requested business operators and citizens of the prefecture to donate medical supplies. Requested medical supplies include medical gowns (surgical gowns and isolation gowns), plastic raincoats, masks (surgical, N95, non-textile masks). Those who have other medical equipment should first call the Nara Coronavirus Material Procurement and Distribution Group.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On May 18, Fukuoka Prefecture and a biotechnology startup, Bonac, agreed to partner and "develop a drug to treat COVID-19 using RNA technology", with a "goal of starting a clinical trial on patients in April 2022".
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From June 2019, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) has established a ONE STOP type of consultation desk in Shimane International Center to respond to various information and consultation regarding to the daily lives of foreign residents. Consultation is free. Since the outbreak in February 2020, the consultation has expanded to specialize in COVID-19 services.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 05-20-20, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will buy 850 camping tents and place them at about 140 designated evacuation centers around the city in an effort to prevent the spread of the coronavirus among their residents amidst the approaching rainy and typhoon seasons.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On May 22, 2020, it was announced that the Government of Japan "will support nine domestic studies aimed at developing a coronavirus vaccine with subsidies totaling 7.2 billion yen, or about 67 million dollars." "The funds are designed to support basic research and segments of clinical trials for an experimental vaccine. The nine projects were selected by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development. Four are led by companies; another four involve universities; and one, a research institute."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Beginning on May 23, the Tottori prefecture (Japan) will be distributing cloth masks for families.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan)  submitted an additional supplementary budget of approximately 2.4 billion yen as the third step of emergency additional support for new coronavirus infectious diseases. This will increase the number of PCR tests to 440 cases and secure more empty beds for hospitalization.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: If a person enrolled in the National Health Insurance System is infected with the new coronavirus (including cases where there is a symptom such as fever and infection is suspected), he/she will be able to pay the injury/illness allowance for the period during which he/she cannot receive labor for medical treatment, as announced by the Okayama prefecture (Japan) on May 27.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Panasonic Corp. announced that they will begin producing approximately 100,000 masks per day at their equipment manufacturing plant in the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) by the end of May to compensate for Japan's growing shortage of masks.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 26, Fukuoka Prefecture allocated 1.7 billion yen to "funding for the development of medical environments" related to COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On June 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo said that "Japan will provide about $300 million to a global organization dedicated to increasing access to vaccinations in developing countries. The financial support to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, will be extended for five years from 2021 to make contributions to global public health efforts. [...] The Japanese government provided around $95 million to Gavi for the previous five-year period from 2016 to 2020. The upcoming donation of $300 million, including $100 million already pledged in April, is the largest amount Japan has provided to the nongovernmental body to date."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On June 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "opened a website where users pick the type of problem they are facing over the novel coronavirus to look for support measures that match their needs." "The website also has a mental health test function." "Smartphone users found to be stressed out can directly seek advice using the Line free messaging app."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description:
On June 12, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) announced the creation of the Consultation Centers for Returning Travelers and
Persons in Contact and Outpatient Clinics for Returning Travelers and
Persons in Contact, available at each healthcare center in Shimane. 
"These centers provide consultation to people suspected of
having COVID-19; they also help people to receive a medical exam at an Outpatient Clinic for
Returning Travelers and Persons in Contact"
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: on 26 June, the Nauru Bulletin announced that Japan granted Nauru AU$1.3  million to enable  the procurement of equipment to support the efficient delivery of health and medical services in Nauru. This will assist with preventing the spread of covid-19 in Nauru.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 29, the governor of the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) announced that the prefecture plans to increase PCR testing capacity from the current 270 tests to 2,400 by March 2021.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Even if the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) has lifted its emergency declaration, the Kokoro Medical Center in Japan will still be restricting hospital visits from July 4. "Only once a week for one person, up to 15 minutes, only for residents in Shimane Prefecture."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 6, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) established the "Hiroshima Prefecture Mental Trouble Consultation [Corona-related]" in order to provide mental care to the residents who feel stress and anxiety due to the effects of the new coronavirus infection.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
As published on July 8, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) has suspended group examinations due to worries about the spread of the coronavirus, switching instead to individual medical checkups of infants and toddlers. Checkpoints will proceed until the end of July. 

"The shift is aimed at preparing health care workers and the wider medical system for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On June 15, 2020, the Minister of Finance of Japan (MOF) "added medical fields to the list of domestic industrial sectors subject to foreign investment restrictions to maintain domestic control over cutting-edge technologies including those related to dealing with the coronavirus pandemic." "The tighter controls on pharmaceutical products and advanced medical equipment under the foreign exchange and foreign trade law will take effect" on July 15, 2020. Already on April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: It was announced on July 22 that Fukuoka Prefecture had "began accepting patients with no or mild symptoms at designated hotels again".
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description:
As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) is implementing hospitalization measures and expanding its inspection measures to prepare for a second wave of the coronavirus. 

"We will work to increase the number of cooperating medical institutions such as clinics that collect samples.

Disseminate saliva collection that can reduce the risk and burden of specimen collection at cooperating medical institutions. To that end, we will work to establish a test system that can smoothly collect and transport samples and increase the number of samples.

Until the testing by saliva collection is available at the cooperating medical institutions, we will expand the induction of PCR tests for those returning to the home or contact of those who are considered to need testing among those who have undergone medical examination."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On July 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has agreed to receive a supply of 120 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine for 60 million people by the end of June next year from U.S. pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE., if they succeed in developing the vaccine."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 11, Fukuoka City's Health and Environment Research Institute introduced the TMA test to perform COVID-19 testing in Fukuoka Prefecture. This test will be used as well along with the PCR test.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: It was announced on August 12 that Fukuoka Prefecture is coordinating with medical institutions to increase the currently secured 490 beds for COVID-19 patients to 760 beds.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to expand the examination system, PCR tests will be made possible in 107 clinics with the cooperation of the prefectural Medical Association.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the health of patients treated at home will be observed through a call centre; delivery of meals will be implemented; and a system will be set up to make treatment at home feel safe.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Japan, on Aug. 12th, 2020, Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it "will open two additional accommodation facilities [...] to accommodate patients who are mild or asymptomatic who do not require hospitalization among positive patients with new coronavirus infection". APA Hotel Asakusa Taharamachi Ekimae with 465 rooms scheduled it's opening for Aug. 13th, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the number of beds secured at medical institutions will be raised from 200 to 425.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the number of rooms at accommodation facilities will be raised from 210 to 340, and further expanded according to the situation.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: As of August 13, the Tottori Prefecture will be providing hotel accommodation for those receiving medical treatment, which will be provides medical services by doctors and nurses with the cooperation of (public corporation) Tottori Medical Associati.on
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "the government is preparing to send hospital and public health nurses to Okinawa Prefecture." "Nurses will be sent from other prefectures as a further spread of infections is expected to strain the island prefectures health care system in terms of hospital beds and personnel." On August 16, 2020, Okinawa Governor Denny Tamaki "asked for such assistance at a meeting with state minister of health Gaku Hashimoto. The central government will work with the National Governors Association so that about 10 hospital nurses will be dispatched within a week. The number will be raised to about 50 eventually. [...] The health ministry will also consider sending to Okinawa medical workers who can handle extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, life support systems and taking COVID-19 patients to hospitals outside the prefecture."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: Japan, on Aug. 12th, 2020, Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it "will open two additional accommodation facilities [...] to accommodate patients who are mild or asymptomatic who do not require hospitalization among positive patients with new coronavirus infection". Tokyo Toranomon Tokyu REI Hotel in Minato with 431 rooms scheduled its opening for Aug. 17th, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced "that over 27,000 hospital beds will be secured across the country for treating patients of the novel coronavirus at the peak of infections. [...] The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that [a]ccording to plans drawn up by the country's 47 prefectures, more than 21,000 rooms will also be secured at accommodation facilities at the peak time for quarantining people with light or no symptoms of the virus, the ministry said. The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "adopted on Friday a plan to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for the whole population of the country by the first half of 2021. The plan was included in the government's policy for its future response to the COVID-19 crisis, adopted at a meeting of its task force on measures against the coronavirus. [...] The government will prepare a legal framework ensuring state compensation in case coronavirus vaccines cause side effects."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that it "will set up a toll-free telephone hotline at 0120-762029 on Sept. 1 to offer consultations to foreigners having trouble making a living due to the pandemic. The service will be available in 14 languages, including Japanese."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Niigata City, Niigata Prefecture in Japan "drive-thru-style clinic was deployed ": ""Drive-through" polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests, in which people suspected of novel coronavirus infection can be tested on the spot without getting out of their cars, have been in use at this central Japan city's public health center since March 1.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced on March 5, 2020, that "[t]ests for COVID-19 will be covered under Japan's national health insurance system starting" from March 6, 2020. "With the insurance coverage, the government will allow people to undergo testing at hospitals or contracted private testing companies without being referred to by health centers."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Oita Prefecture announced on April 1 that the Prefecture and Oita City jointly have a total COVID-19 "testing capacity of up to 132 persons per day".
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Starting from 3 April 0:00 JST, PCR tests will be conducted on arrival for those who have visited, within 14 days prior to their entry into Japan, countries and regions subjected to entry bans.

description: On 04-15-20, eighteen people at a social welfare facility in Hiroshima (Japan) have been newly confirmed infected with the novel coronavirus, the city government, and the government conducted virus tests on people related to the facility.

description: On April 17, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "expand testing with drive-thru facilities and general practitioners helping to collect samples." During a news conference, Abe declared that "[w]ith help from regional medical associations, we will set up testing centers. If home doctors have decided testing is necessary, test samples are taken at these centers and sent to private inspection firms."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Japan, "Yokosuka City in Kanagawa Prefecture will introduce a method called "walk-through method" to collect samples for PCR test and open a new inspection site" on Apr.17th. 40 tests can be done per day.

target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: On April 20, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) "has changed the definition of people who had close contact with patients of the COVID-19 disease, caused by the novel coronavirus. According to the new definition, people who were at a distance of one meter, enough to touch by hand, from an infected person for 15 minutes or more without taking infection prevention measures, such as wearing a face mask, two days before the person started to display symptoms or later are regarded as those with close contact with the patient."
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 22, Okayama Gov. Ryuta Ibaragi (Japan) announced that the prefecture will check the temperatures of visitors from the Kinki region, where many cases of infections were reported, at a highway parking area.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that MHLW "has begun checking the performance of several test kits that could be used to see the existence of coronavirus antibodies in blood samples." The Minister stated that "the ministry began the evaluation to pave the way for a quick implementation of antibody testing in Japan."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On April 26, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to allow dentists to collect samples from people suspected of being infected with coronavirus in an effort to strengthen the countrys ability to conduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for detecting infection." "Dentists who have taken relevant training will be able collect samples from patients at the special outpatient facilities for a certain period."

description: On May 13, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government "began a study into whether sewage samples can be used to detect signs of a spread of novel coronavirus infections. To prepare for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections, the metropolitan government aims to establish a method to analyze sewage for the virus in cooperation with the Japan Society on Water Environment." "The metropolitan government will collect 300 milliliters of treated and untreated sewage samples once a week at 15 sewage treatment plants in the nations capital."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Aichi Prefecture Government installed PCR drive-through test sites in Parking lots on May 15.

description: On 21st May, Nagoya City in Aichi Prefecture, Japan established a 'drive-thru' style PCR test location for health testing purposes. The policy is aimed generally at people with light symptoms. On 14/09/2020, Mayor of Nagoya City Kawamura Takashi announced that this test facility would close on 30/09/2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: The government will start testing 10,000 people in Tokyo, Osaka and Miyagi prefectures for coronavirus antibodies next month as part of efforts to better understand how it spreads.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 24, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to fully cover the cost of coronavirus PCR tests for near-term pregnant women." "Specifically, the ministry will provide subsidies to local governments subject to some conditions, which include that they decide in advance where to accept pregnant women who test positive."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Government of Japan"will conduct testing for coronavirus antibodies in Tokyo and two other prefectures, starting early next month for about 10,000 people." "The test will cover Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture, where the number of coronavirus cases per 100,000 people is relatively large, and Miyagi Prefecture, which has fewer cases."
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
target_province: Tokyo Prefecture; Osaka Prefecture; Miyagi Prefecture

description: On May 15, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Ministry "will conduct COVID-19 antibody testing for about 10,000 people as early as next month. The testing will cover several prefectures, including those with many coronavirus cases and those with a few cases. The ministry plans to find out whether people have antibodies against the new coronavirus and the amount of antibodies a person has."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On June 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "it has approved the use of saliva samples in polymerase chain reaction tests for the novel coronavirus. Saliva use is available within nine days after people start developing symptoms of COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by the coronavirus. [...] The new method is less risky as saliva samples are enclosed in special containers by patients themselves," thus reducing the "infection risks to medical workers."
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
Due to a new confirmed case of COVID-19 on July 2 in Tottori City, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) is conducting PCR tests on its citizens, as announced on July 14.  

"We are actively conducting PCR testing; if you are concerned about possible infection, please first contact the Shimane International Centers One Stop Center Consultation hotline for foreign residents."
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 15, 2020, the Okinawa Chubu Central Hospital (Okinawa, Japan) "started collecting specimens for antibody surveys to be carried out by the Okinawa Prefectural Government in partnership with the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) for a survey of the state of coronavirus infection in Okinawa. [...] The same will be carried out at the Public Kumejima Hospital. Collection of antibodies will start at prefectural hospitals in the northern and southern parts of Okinawa Island, Miyako, and Yaeyama as soon as approval is received from the ethics review committee."
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
At the event "The ROSE" in Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan), held on July 10th (Friday), multiple people with the new type coronavirus infections occurred.

"In response, the Fukuyama City Public Health Center has called on bar users to undergo PCR testing."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On July 25, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) "began PCR testing for Japanese citizens who work in the U.S. bases." "By July 24, Okinawa had contacted the over 800 people who work at Camp Hansen and MCAS Futenma through organization such as the Okinawa Defense Bureau (ODB) for testing." A testing site was established at "a community center in Okinawa City."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen border measures, the TACO system at Naha Airport will be enhanced by opening up the possibility of antigen testing.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of hygienic measures on its village ferries by crew members, such as wearing of masks, hand washing, disinfection of equipments and supplies, proper coughing etiquette, and air ventilation. Customers are expected to collaborate. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requests residents to wash hands and practice coughing etiquette between April 7 and May 6.
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description:
Japan, on Apr. 22 Tokyo government announce, that it will "implement an emergency support project (new coronavirus infectious disease emergency measures) for ensuring safety and security for taxi and bus operators."
"Measures to prevent splash infection by separating the driver's seat and rear seat in a taxi" and "infection-prevention equipment on sightseeing buses" will be installed.
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: On April 27, 2020, the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ) announced that it will "provide subsidies to help restaurants introduce high-performance ventilation systems to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus." "The subsidies will be paid to cover half to two-thirds of costs to install such advanced ventilation systems, which each costs about 500,000 yen. The ministry expects that the aid will cover a total of some 3,000 ventilation systems at 800 to 1,000 locations across the nation."
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture has extended the request for residents to wash hands and practice coughing etiquette from "May 7th to 31st". UPDATE: Original policy set to last until May 6, but extended to May 31.

description:
In Sendai starting from May 14, 2020 in regards to restaurants: as a measure to prevent new coronavirus infectious diseases, keep in mind the latest information (policy and advice) that is appropriately released from the national and local governments.
Continue business while ensuring that the following basic items are met.
<U+2713> Food safety and hygiene management
<U+2713> Cleaning and disinfection of stores and facilities
<U+2713> Check employee health and thoroughly manage individual health and hygiene
<U+2713> Device for setting and securing social distance
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked business operators to comply with the "Infection Spread Prevention Guidelines" and to make use of the "shisa sticker"-system (which certifies compliance to the prefectural recommendation), "in order to minimize the impact on economic activities while strengthening infection control measures."
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked managers, staff and visitors of social welfare facilities, hospitals, and other facilities where people with a high risk of serious illnesses reside, to carefully follow measures of infection prevention.
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied

description: On August 18, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) announced that "All kinds of vehicles have been filled with smoke to demonstrate ventilation performance. description:
On April 26, 2020, the Governor of Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) Denny Tamaki asked tourists "to stay away this year.
Startled and alarmed by the fact that thousands of people are still expected to travel to the southernmost island prefecture, Tamaki on April 26 posted a message on Twitter pleading, "Please cancel your trip to Okinawa now."
"I am sorry to tell you this but Okinawa is under a state of emergency," Tamaki wrote. "There is no way we can provide the very best omotenashi (hospitality)." Tamaki is hoping to change people's minds about flying across the country to Okinawa while Japan is under the national state of emergency to control the spread of the novel coronavirus."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On July 31, 2020, Kudaka Island, Nanjo (Okinawa, Japan) issued a call for self-restraint in visiting the island. "The request takes effect on August 1 and will continue for the time being. The announcement asked for everyone's cooperation, emphasizing that Kudaka Island has a large elderly population and a fragile healthcare system, and that infections there would be an 'emergency that would threaten the continued existence of the island.'" The island called for special care in respecting the restraint during three time frames: From August 1 until August 10; from August 29 until September 5; and from September 23 until September 30, 2020.

description: On February 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "attended the first Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting at the Prime Ministers Office" and called for contributions from "experts who are working on the front line in the respective fields, to give due consideration based on the medical and scientific perspectives, including the characteristics of the virus and other knowledge we have gathered so far", adding that the "Government will introduce further countermeasures in advance, following the advice based on the medical and scientific perspectives proposed by this expert meeting." The Expert Meeting was announced on February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters: "in order to advance deliberations over our countermeasures based on expert knowledge even more than ever before, we will establish an expert meeting under this Headquarters, which consist of infectious disease specialists working on the frontline in their respective fields, and strengthen our responses."

description:
On 6 July 2020, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education established a "talent pool" or "human resources bank" to assemble people who can work in schools at the primary, middle and high school levels as temporary teachers or support staff. Whilst schools are currently closed, many are concerned that COVID-19 will delay children's learning and so, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education will organise supplementary classes once schools reopen and ask those who apply to lead these classes and those without current teaching qualifications will be asked to provide support. Those who successfully register in the human resources bank will be able to address teacher shortages within schools if teachers are infected by COVID-19. In addition to temporary teachers, this human resources bank aims to assemble 550 learning instructors to assist with after-school supplementary classes and 140 school support staff to help with class preparations.

This human resources bank was established separately to the National Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology's human resources bank.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 8 August 2020 the governors of Japans 47 prefectures conducted a video meeting and compiled a list of urgent proposals to the national government in response to COVID19 The proposals include A request to increase the amount of extraordinary grants for local governments to fund various measures against the coronavirus pandemic  A revision to the special law for combating the coronavirus so that authorities can impose penalties on business operators that fail to cooperate with businesssuspension requests by local governments To consider extending the Go To Travel campaign so that tourismrelated industries and local economies can sufficiently recover In particular the areas impacted by torrential rains in July 2020  To provide more PCR test support and resources To increase dissemination of information on COVID19 to foreign nationals living in Japan through embassies and other means  Strongly request measures to prevent the spread of COVID19 at US military bases  To take action to eliminate prejudice discriminatory behavior and false rumoursThe governors also advise that people reconsider making trips during the Bon summer holiday season around the middle of August amid concern that the movement of people will spread the virus further
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

The agency expects applicants to find jobs in agriculture, food and beverage manufacturing and other sectors suffering severe personnel shortages."

description: On May 10, 2020, the Japan Society for Oriental Medicine announced that it "is set to study whether and how ethical herbal medicines and antipyretics given to novel coronavirus patients for symptomatic treatment have led to worsening in their conditions. The organization asked medical institutions in the country to provide data, including details of the drugs prescribed to patients and suspected patients of the COVID-19 disease from the virus to contain their fevers or coughs, developments of their symptoms in the 14 days since the start of treatment and whether their symptoms worsened or not. The group hopes to collect data on about 1,000 cases and analyze the data using a statistical method."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On May 12, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "[i]n light of the various circumstances associated with the impact of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) and from the perspective of preventing its spread, as a measure to reduce congestion at the immigration counters for residency applications, the immigration counters will be accepting applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay from those foreign nationals (excluding foreign nationals with the status of residence of Designated Activities (Departure Preparation Period)) whose expiration date (see note) for their period of stay is due in March, April, May June or July for an extended period of three months from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national." UPDATE: Visas expiring in July as well will receive a three-month extension.
