description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting called for "swift and accurate information to the citizens, and endeavour to ensure safety and security." Moreover, the Ministerial Meeting prompted to "pay sufficient attention when handling personal information of infected persons."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On January 24, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe asked "that the public strictly adhere to prevention measures against the common cold and behave calmly without overly reacting."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: In Tokyo [Japan], a telephone consultation service (call center) has been set up since January 29 (Wednesday), in response to outbreaks of new coronavirus infectious diseases, to respond to consultations from residents of Tokyo.

description: On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced a hotline for "general consultations related to COVID-19" on February 25.

description: On May 22, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government, Japan, announced that "[p]eople in Tokyo will soon be able to find out if the city is managing to contain the coronavirus by looking at [...] [t]he Rainbow Bridge, which [...] will be illuminated in seven colors after the city's state of emergency is lifted." description: On May 9, Fukuoka Prefecture shared "revised guidelines" in preparation for a "disaster combined with circumstances involving the spread of COVID-19" and have advised "cities and towns" to revise their manuals "in accordance with the new guidelines by the end of May". Guidelines call for the avoidance of "closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings" as well as "the use of additional accommodation facilities".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On 17 June 2020, Nara Prefecture in the lead up to the annual monsoon season/ rainy season during which Japan is prone is disasters, shared on their website evacuation guidelines and procedures. Furthermore, these guidelines include recommendations on how to prevent the spread of covid-19 during evacuation and refuge. 

In addition to basic stockpiling, Nara Prefecture asks citizens to prepare: masks, a thermometer, plastic bags, disinfectant solution/ hand sanitiser, wet tissues and towels.

In evacuation shelters, they ask citizens to wear masks, practicing good hygiene such as hand washing and cooperate with others in the shelter. To support this, the Prefecture has attached guides on hand washing,  hand washing without water, cough etiquette and hygiene management of shelter toilets. 

This policy includes and supports material produced by the National Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
The Tottori Prefecture (Japan) announced on June 23 to its citizens to install the new coronavirus contact confirmation app "COCOA".
 "The new coronavirus contact confirmation application "COCOA" of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is a smartphone application that allows you to receive notifications about the possibility of contact with a person infected with a new coronavirus infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo," declaring that the "current situation is not as tense as it was in April, when the government declared a state of emergency over the pandemic." Prime Minister Abe Shinzo "called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 22, 2020, the Government of Japan kicked off the "Go To Travel campaign", a discount travel campaign. The campaign will be financed with 1.35 trillion yen "to promote domestic travel by anyone to any destination [within Japan] they wished with an up to a 50 percent discount via deals and vouchers. [...] But after a spike in coronavirus cases in Tokyo, the government announced a sudden decision to exclude travel to and from the capital." "The government hopes to support the tourism industry, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, while taking care not to spread the virus further. Travel and accommodation businesses are required to take full precautions."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 5, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) opened two official LINE accounts ("Okinawa Prefecture Official LINE Account" and "Okinawa Prefecture - Corona Countermeasures Personal Support") in order to send institutional information concerning the prefecture and spread information about new coronavirus infectious disease.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Kagoshima Prefecture set up a COVID-19 consultation call center on August 6 to respond to COVID-19 related enquiries from citizens and businesses. The line is available 24/7 and a fax option is also available. There is also 24/7 support available in English, Chinese, Korean, Spanish and Portuguese. Support in Vietnamese and Thai is available on weekdays from 10am to 6pm.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 19, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) established a hygiene counseling service for businesses that operate accommodation facilities, restaurants, etc., and are confused about measures to prevent infection, measures to take if an infected person occurs, and refrain from reducing sales.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 21, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) opened a consultation dial to receive appropriate advice and information from dedicated staff 24 hours a day, directly for various consultations regarding symptoms related to new-type coronavirus infectious diseases, infection prevention, inspection methods, etc.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that from February 1, 2020, "it has become possible to implement measures as a Designated Infectious Disease, including hospitalization for the patients infected by the novel coronavirus."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "Japan will revise an ordinance to enable the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine". From February 14, 2020, authorities will be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms. [...] Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 13, 2020, at the Eight Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government will designate, from February 14, 2020, "the novel coronavirus as an infection subject to quarantine or detention in accordance with the Quarantine Act with a government ordinance to ensure the thorough prevention of infections."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that, from February 14, 2020 onwards, "the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine" will be allowed. Authorities will also be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms." "Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 18, 2020, at the Eleventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe invited "the public [...] to refrain from going outside, taking leave from school or work, when experiencing symptoms of a cold, such as a fever. [...] Creating an environment that makes it easy for students and employees to take days off is crucial and I would like to ask cooperation in this regard. Making use of means like tele-working is another effective approach."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: On February 26, the Tottori prefecture (Japan) urged all persons entering Japan from any region where there is a high risk of new coronavirus pneumonia infection, notably China, to apply for quarantine if they are experiencing any symptoms of cough or fever.

description: On April 7, 2020, the Welfare Department of Tarama Island and Tarama Clinic asked residents to "refrain from visiting relatives from outside the island. Return home and leave only for basic shopping." [loose translation from Japanese]

Japan annouced on March 4 that it will cease to display masks on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14" and "Mobaoku announced on March 5 that it will cease to display masks and antiseptics on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14."

description: On March 21, 2020, "Japan Transocean Air (JTA) announced their plan to suspend 60 flight routes from Naha, Fukuoka, Miyako, and Ishigaki from March 29 through April 5. This decision was made due to reduced demand from passengers amidst the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The suspensions include 10 routes between Fukuoka and Naha, 26 routes between Naha and Miyako, and 24 routes between Naha and Ishigaki."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
Oita Prefecture announced on April 1 that "workplaces that remain open for essential social and economic services" should: 
1. "Thoroughly carry out precautionary measures (e.g. handwashing, good cough etiquette) in an out of the office and during commute" 
2. "Proactively incorporate telecommuting, staggered work hours and commute on bicycle"
3.  If staff show "fever or symptoms of cold", "refrain from working (or make alternative work arrangements such as telecommuting) and remain at home"
4. "Employ alternative work arrangements such as video conferences to cut back travel on business trips"
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: From April 2, 2020, Japan Post "has announced that it will temporarily stop accepting international mail destined for 153 countries. For 126 of those countries, the suspension is limited to EMS and air mail", whereas any type of delivery is suspended for the remaining 27. Moreover, "[i]tems which have already been accepted and cannot be dispatched to their destinations will be returned from the delivery offices to the senders in order."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 1, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo invited airlines to "reduce the number of arriving air flight passengers from overseas" during the 25th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, by "[r]equesting airlines concerned to curb the number of arrival passengers to Japan by such measures as reducing the number of passenger arrival flights in order to ensure the appropriate implementation of quarantine measures." The measures should be implemented by April 3, 2020 0:00 JST "until the end of April, for the time being."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Makishi Public Market in Naha City, Okinawa, Japan, "has closed for two weeks [on April 4, 2020 at 5:30 p.m.,] after a worker was confirmed to be infected with the new coronavirus" on the same day.

description: On April 6, 2020 "the Minami-Daito Novel Coronavirus Task Force (led by Mayor Kensho Nakada) held its third meeting at the village hall. With infections spreading domestically and internationally, the Task Force requested that tourists as well as business travelers on non-essential, non-urgent business refrain from visiting the island. These requests were made to the Village Tourism Association and the Village Commerce and Industry Association respectively. Hotels and other lodgings are moving toward not accepting reservations through the end of April."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requested that between April 7 and May 6 that workers should "reduce contact" with people by working from home (telework), staggering work hours, and commuting by bike.

type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium (Okinawa, Japan) and adjoined facilities close temporarily from April 7, 2020.

The museum reopening and ticket sales will be announced on the museum official homepage, Twitter, LINE and LAWSON ticket homepage when it is determined safe to resume operations." description:
The Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) has requested all related businesses to take leave as described in Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Act on Special Measures against Countermeasures against New Influenza, etc., announced on April 20. 

"From April 16th to May 6th, Reiwa, the "Emergency Declaration" was issued to all prefectures, and we are strongly calling for the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unnecessarily and urgently. There is concern about an increase in the inflow of people from neighboring prefectures, which are expanding rapidly, to entertainment and amusement facilities."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Apr. 20 Fukushima governor requests "closure of facilities except for ones essential for sustaining our daily lives such as hospitals, pharmacies, grocery stores, public transportation, as well as social welfare facilities including nurseries, certified daycare centers, after-school child-care service facilities and senior care facilities." from Apr. 21 to May 6.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: From April 22 to May 6, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) requests large-scale stores such as department stores and various shops and facilities such as leisure facilities to be closed.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Japan, on Apr. 22 Nagano prefecture requests non-essential businesses to close from Apr. 23 until May 6. Facilities subject to the requests include hostess bars, karaoke parlors, game arcades, movie theaters and pachinko parlors. Restaurants, including izakaya pubs, will be asked to stop serving alcohol at 7 p.m. and close at 8 p.m. Furthermore, museums, exhibition halls and hotels will be closed too.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The Prefecture asks that from April 23rd to May 6th, certain facilities suspend their activities in accordance with Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law. These include: recreation facilities, exercise and amusement facilities, theaters, private cram schools, driving schools, meeting/ exhibition facilities, commercial facilities other than stores that sell daily-necessities (essential goods).
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Although some facilities were asked to suspend their activities between 23 April and 6 May (which encompasses Golden Week), some are asked to remain open. Facilities that are requested to continue operating include: medical facilities, facilities for daily necessities (encompassing wholesale markets, grocery stores, essential goods sections in department stores, hardware stores, supermarkets, convenience stores), accomodation facilities, transportation, factories, financial institutions (banks, stock exchanges, insurance companies), media organisations, funeral homes, public baths, pawnshops, veterinarians, beauty salons, laundromats and garbage disposal related facilities.

However, these facilities/ services are asked to implement appropriate infection control measures or encourage remote work where possible. 

Restaurants and other hospitality businesses (including taverns) are also allowed to open, but with infection control measures and are asked to shorten opening hours and terminate the sale of alcoholic beverages at 7pm.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On April 23, 2020, the Government of Japan "notified the country's 47 prefectures of guidelines on procedures for publishing the names of business operators that defy requests for suspending operations amid the novel coronavirus pandemic."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy
of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "issued guidelines on what kind of steps governors can take to get business owners that continue to ignore government requests to suspend their operations." "The guidelines say governors are authorized to issue stronger "requests" or "instructions" to those who refuse to comply with initial requests without legitimate reasons.
The names and addresses of the businesses given such stronger warnings will be disclosed online or by other means."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Hokkaido Prefecture requested that supermarkets enforce special "infection prevention measures" from April 24 to May 6.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On April 24, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Osaka, Japan, "revealed the names of six pachinko pinball parlors that have not followed its request to shut down in the fight against the novel coronavirus. It is the first time that the names of uncooperative businesses have been made public under Article 45 of the special coronavirus response law."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: From April 2, 2020, Japan Post announced that the "temporary suspension of acceptance of international mail items, mainly EMS and parcel-post/letter- post items by air and SAL, started on April 2, will be extended for the time being from April 24." "Items which have already been accepted and cannot be dispatched to their destinations will be returned from the delivery offices to the senders in order. In addition, because of the global reduction of flights, considerable delivery delays are expected for outbound mail items to other countries/territories." UPDATE: Extended from April 24, 2020.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Apr. 21 Akita prefecture requests non-essential businesses to close from Apr. 25 until May 6. description: On April 20, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the suspension of the High-Speed Queen Zamami ferry service from April 25, 2020 until May 6, 2020, along with time schedule changes for Ferry Zamami. In addition, during the same period, the inter-island Mitsushima route (between Zamami Island and Aka Island) will operate as scheduled, but the route to Aharen (which connects Zamami Island to Tokashiki Island) will be suspended.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On April 23, Fukui requests the suspension of business in Fukui as a part of emergency measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This measure will be maintained until May 6.

description:
On April 25, the Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) announced this: 
"To the citizens of the Yamaguchi prefecture, in order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, refrain from going out, except for those who need to visit the hospital, purchase food, medicines and daily necessities, and keep outdoor activities such as exercise and walking. 

On the other hand, it has been pointed out that it is necessary to prevent infections in places such as supermarkets, shopping malls, and parks that are used by many people. Please take note of the following and cooperate with us in preventing the spread of infections.
* Keep the number of people small and avoid crowds, and keep the distance between people appropriately.
* Observe the request to prevent infection at the place of use."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On May 1, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced that the operation of Ferry Zamami will be suspended every Tuesday but that the High-Speed Queen Zamami ferry service will be restored every Tuesday. Schedules have been re-arranged to enable day trips to Okinawa Main Island. Moreover, the route to Aharen (which connects Zamami Island to Tokashiki Island) will be suspended. These measures will be effective from May 11, 2020. UPDATE: Change on suspension schedule.

description: On May 14, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, <U+7D4C><U+56E3><U+9023>) released guidelines "for protecting workers from COVID-19 are expected to be referred to when companies resume business activities while taking precautionary measures, following the government's lifting of the coronavirus state of emergency for most of the country's 47 prefectures. The guidelines are intended for long-term use at least until treatment for the disease is established and a vaccine is developed." Moreover, it "called on member companies to introduce a four-day workweek system to reduce coronavirus infection risks" and suggested "further promotion of remote working, staggered commuting and social-distancing measures in workplaces." Keidanren asked companies to "take measures, keeping in mind that steps taken at workplaces will lead to the prevention of a further spread of the virus across the entire society."
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

gym, sports classroom" until May 31.

description:
On March 12, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (Tokyo, Tokyo Prefecture) announced an extension of its closure, originally planned until March 15, 2020, from March 16, 2020 until March 31, 2020. UPDATE: "The observatories of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building are both closed for preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), the period of closure will be extended as below.
Period of closure : From Monday 16th March to Tuesday 31st March 2020."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Since the declaration of state of emergency on April 7, 2020, the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) have decreased "the number of people who commute to work by utilizing teleworking" and implemented "measures for double shifts in various divisions". Large-scale trainings for new personnel and large meetings are being avoided. Within its diplomatic missions abroad, MOFA has been promoting infection control measures "such as hand-washing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work". In addition, "various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary", and officials "either work at home or commute to work" according to a "split-team structure". Over-the-counter services have been affected by "shortened counter hours", the introduction of "appointment systems", and extensions to "document processing times".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7 and April 9, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued declarations concerning MOFAs structure and efforts in the case of the declaration of a state of emergency, which was realised on  Planned and adopted measures include teleworking, the introduction of a split-team structure where personnel [is divided] into two teams that either work at home or commute to work, including for diplomatic missions, and decrease of the total number of hours spent working in person at MOFA. Moreover, diplomatic missions have been taking infection control measures in the same way as MOFA including thoroughly promoting practices such as handwashing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work. Also, various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On April 9, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (Tokyo, Tokyo Prefecture) announced an extension of its closure, originally planned until April 12, 2020, now until May 6, 2020. UPDATE: "The observatories of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building are both closed for preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), the period of closure will be extended as below.
until Wednesday 6th May 2020"

type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: "Senior Japanese ruling party and opposition officials agreed [on April 13, 2020] to cut the daily number of meetings of committees of the Diet, the country's parliament, and that of participating lawmakers in order to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus", in line with the goal of "reducing human-to-human contact in the country by 80%".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On 21 April 2020, the Nara Prefecture Foreigner Support Centre announced changes to the operations of the foreign resident counselling service and the international student room. From 22 April 2020, the foreign resident counselling service will only be operating by telephone and email. In-person consultations and the dispatch of translators will be limited. The operations of the international student room will also be limited to telephone and email from Monday to Friday 9AM to 5PM. These modifications will be in place until the state of emergency is lifted in the prefecture.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:
From 22 April 2020, in light of the state of emergency declaration, the business hours of the passport application and passport handover windows at the Nara Prefecture Passport Office and the Takada Passport Centre will be modified. 

From 18 May onwards, the Nara Prefecture Passport Office and the Takada Passport Centre will resume normal business hours. UPDATE: The original policy adjusted the opening hours of the passport offices in light of covid-19. From May 18th, normal business hours will resume, meaning, the end of the policy

type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

From 18 May onwards, the Nara Prefecture Passport Office and the Takada Passport Centre will resume normal business hours. UPDATE: The original policy adjusted the opening hours of the passport offices in light of covid-19. From May 18th, normal business hours will resume, meaning, the end of the policy
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Other public facilities

description: In order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection, the Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) has decided to discontinue the use of playground equipment in the prefectural city park, as announced on April 23. This will take place from April 25 to May 10 at Yamaguchi Children's Center (Menshin Memorial Park), Yamaguchi Kirara Memorial Park, Hagi Wellness Park.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: To minimise crowds and suppress the number of people travelling within the prefecture, as well as to and from the prefecture, the Nara Prefecture has asked persons to refrain from going out during the Golden Week period (April 25th to May 6th). To support this, the Prefecture will also close parking lots under the jurisdiction of the Nara Prefecture Department of Water Recycling, Forests and Environment during Golden Week. Specifically, the parking lots at Yatayama Play Forest and Odaigahara.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: In order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection during the long holiday period, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) decided to close parking lots at "roadside stations" in the prefecture, as announced on April 28. "Of the 24 road stations in the prefecture, we will close 7 places, 4 places managed by the prefecture and 3 places managed by the municipality."

description: In order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection during the long holiday period, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) decided to close parking lots at "roadside stations" in the prefecture, as announced on April 28. "Of the 24 road stations in the prefecture, we will close 7 places, 4 places managed by the prefecture and 3 places managed by the municipality."

description:
On May 1, 2020, the Cabinet of the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe 
"held its first meeting using a videoconferencing system." "Abe and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga took part in the meeting from the same room at the prime minister's office, while other ministers called in from their respective ministry or agency offices."

description:
On May 1, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (Tokyo, Tokyo Prefecture) announced, it will extend the temporary closure, previously set until May 6, for the time being.
 UPDATE: The observatories of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building are closed for preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), the period of closure will be extended until being.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

 UPDATE: The observatories of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building are closed for preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), the period of closure will be extended until being.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description:
On 8 May 2020, Nara Prefecture announced the temporary closure of "Nara Mahoroba-kan"- a souvenir store and tourism centre. The "Nara Mahoroba-kan" will be closed until May 31st. 

From 1 June "Nara Mahorobakan" will reopen but with reduced opening hours. Between June 1st to 12th, the business hours will be 11:00 to 19:00 (Usually from 10:30 to 19:30). UPDATE: The Prefecture operated souvenir store and tourist centre had originally been closed due to the spread of covid-19. From 1 June onwards, "Nara Mahoroba-kan" will reopen with reduced opening hours until 12 June.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:

From 1 June onwards, "Nara Mahoroba-kan" will reopen with reduced opening hours until 12 June.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On 8 May 2020, Nara Prefecture announced the temporary closure of "Nara Mahoroba-kan"- a souvenir store and tourism centre. The "Nara Mahoroba-kan" was be closed until May 31st. 
   
From 1 June "Nara Mahorobakan" will reopen but with reduced opening hours. Between June 1st to 12th, the business hours will be 11:00 to 19:00 (Usually from 10:30 to 19:30).

description: Osaka Prefecture in Japan announced on 19 February 2020 that it would cancel or postpone all public events sponsored or co-sponsored by the prefectural government for one month (ending on 20 March 2020) as a precautionary measure against COVID-19
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On February 17, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency announced the cancellation of the "public birthday event for Emperor Naruhito at the Imperial Palace", which was originally scheduled for February 23, 2020. "Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako were originally scheduled to greet the public three times on Sunday morning [(February 23, 2020)] from a balcony in the palace's Chowa-Den wing, together with Crown Prince Fumihito and his wife Crown Princess Kiko and their daughters Princess Mako and Princess Kako."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 26, 2020, the Zamami Village Tourism Association of the island of Zamami (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has announced the cancellation of the annual Whale Music Festival, scheduled to be held on March 21, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On February 26, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) compiled the Response Policy regarding the handling of prefecture-sponsored events related to the prevention of the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases. Prefecture-sponsored events occurring in two prefectures will be cancelled or postponed.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On February 27, 2020, at the 15th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for implementation of measures to prevent infections and limited number of participants at school entrance examinations or graduation ceremonies.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 27 February 2020, in light of the spread of COVID-19, the Nara Prefecture announced the cancellation of 84th food festival market and the 14th "Naraichiba no Kitchen event. Both were scheduled for the 29th February 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On February 17, 2020, Tokyo Marathon organisers announced that the "Tokyo Marathon 2020 will be held only for the marathon elites and the wheelchair elites." The event "was expected to have 38,000 people taking part" and was scheduled for March 1, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 25, Saga Prefecture and co-host, Asias 50 Best Restaurants, announced that they have cancelled "Asia's 50 Best Restaurants 2020" award ceremony which was to be held on March 24.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On February 26, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has announced the cancellation of the Zamami village memorial service ceremony, scheduled to take place on March 27, 2020 and meant to celebrate the 75 anniversary since the end of the Second World War, due to the new coronavirus infection. On March 26, 2020, villagers might still freely visit the Peace Tower for individual worship services.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 24 March 2020, the Nara Prefecture announced the cancellation of the 85th food festival market. This wholesale market was originally scheduled for the 28th March 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: "Japan's Imperial Household Agency said [on April 13, 2020] that it has decided to cancel this year's Imperial spring garden party, scheduled for May 27, because of the spread of the novel coronavirus. The event was due to be hosted by Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako. The agency holds a garden party hosted by the country's Emperor and Empress in spring and autumn every year, at the Akasaka Imperial estate in the Motoakasaka district in Tokyo's Minato Ward, with some 2,000 guests."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Due to COVID-19, Kumamoto Prefecture "scaled down" a ceremony to mark the fourth anniversary of two earthquakes. The number of attendees was reduced from 350 to 26 and "spaces between seats were widened to minimize person-to-person contact and help prevent infection".

description: As announced on April 24, all competitions will be canceled for the 63rd Tottori (Japan) Civic Sports Festival in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus infections.

description: On April 26, 2020, the All Japan High School Athletic Federation "decided to cancel this year's Interscholastic Athletic Meet," (otherwise known as Inter-High School Sports Festival) scheduled to be held from August 10, 2020 to August 24, 2020 "in venues in 21 prefectures." description: On May 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced its "plan to utilize provisional release actively for foreigners detained in custody facilities before deportation due to illegal stays and other reasons." "The agency decided to utilize provisional release actively for detainees with no infection symptoms, except for those who have committed serious crimes, as custody facilities often have enclosed and congested environments involving close contact, with high infection risks. In addition, the guidelines include isolating new detainees for around two weeks and limiting visits to detainees to consular officers and lawyers."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture "has implemented a ban on fishing and related activities" at the Tsuyazaki, Unoshima, Oshima and Oronoshima Fishery Ports from May 2 until May 6.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Japan Sumo Association "has canceled the summer grand tournament in Tokyo due to the coronavirus pandemic." "The tournament was set to open on May 24 at the Ryogoku Kokugikan arena in the Japanese capital after a two-week postponement from its initial schedule due to the pandemic."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Kagoshima Prefecture has requested residents from April 17 to May 6 to "avoid holding events" to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

description: As a part of measures made by Ishikawa prefecture's state of emergency, Ishikawa requested citizens to refrain from unnecessary social gathering and outing from April 16 to May 6. As the end of the prefectural state of emergency extended from May 6 to May 31, this request for self-refraining from unnecessary gathering and outing also extended at the same periods. UPDATE: As the end of the prefectural state of emergency extended from May 6 to May 31, this request for self-refraining from unnecessary gathering and outing also extended at the same periods.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture has extended the request for residents to "avoid poorly ventilated spaces, crowded spaces where people gather, and close contact of conversation" from May 7 to May 31. UPDATE: Original policy set to end on May 6, but has been extended to May 31.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requested residents to "refrain from events and gatherings that have poorly ventilated spaces, crowded spaces, and close contact which may lead to the spread of the infection" from May 7 to May 31. UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until May 6, but has been extended until May 31.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) has decided to cancel the entire schedule for the "National Sports Festival for the Disabled" on May 31 event in order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection, as announced on May 10.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 14, 2020, the Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri executive committee announced "that they would be canceling the 65th Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri (hosted by the executive committee: Okinawa City, Ryukyu Shimpo Co. Ltd., Okinawa Television, the Okinawa Tourism and Industry Promotion Association, and the Okinawa City Youth Council), originally scheduled for September 11-13, due to concerns over the coronavirus." "The festival takes place at Okinawa City Stadium" in Okinawa City, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan, featuring "Eisa performances by groups from Okinawa City and elsewhere."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On March 25, 2020, "the Okinawa Peace Movement Center (Chairman Hiroji Yamashiro) held an action committee meeting, at which it was decided that the 43rd 5/15 Peace March would be cancelled." "The rally, which was to be held on the final day of the event, was also cancelled. These actions were taken as measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus." "The 5/15 Peace March is held every year to draw attention to the importance of peace. The event spans 3 days, falling around May 15 when Okinawa was returned to mainland Japan."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 15, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Yamanashi (Japan) announced that "it would shut the route on its side to the top of the Japan's tallest mountain," Mount Fuji (Yoshida trail). "Usually, the Fujinomiya, Subashiri and Gotenba trails on the Shizuoka side and the Yoshida trail on the Yamanashi side open between July and September."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On May 18, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Shizuoka (Japan) announced that "it will close all three trails on Mount Fuji on the central Japan prefecture's side this summer, following the spread of the novel coronavirus."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On May 20, 2020, "the Japan High School Baseball Federation and The Asahi Shimbun, a sponsor of the tournament, decided on the cancellation" of the summer National High School Baseball Championship, which was scheduled to start on August 10, 2020, "because of the novel coronavirus pandemic. At the same time, the prefectural tournaments to determine the 49 competing teams in the summer championship were also scrapped."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 25, in line with the national and prefectural government policies of holding events, the Standard Guidelines for Events and Gatherings Organized by the City of Hiroshima (Japan) were revised at the Hiroshima City COVID-19 Countermeasures Headquarters Meeting.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
In order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus in Sendai City, it was decided to cancel or postpone events that gather a large number of people indoors, events that provide meals, etc. In response to the change in the handling policy, we will gradually relax the event holding restrictions.
However, in principle, we will continue to suspend or postpone large-scale events that involve the movement of people across the country and wide-area events and events for which the risk of infection cannot be fully addressed.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Kyoto Prefecture of Japan is implementing restrictions on outdoor events to have less than 200 participants, and there must be an allowance for the proper maintenance of distances between people (2 meters where possible) until June 18th.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Kyoto Prefecture of Japan has implemented a restriction on indoor events to limit the number of participants to be 100 maximum, and the number of participants to not exceed half of the capacity of the venue until June 18th.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Until May 31st, for the types of facilities that have experienced cluster outbreaks, Kyoto Prefecture asked people to cooperate in the restriction of their usage.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
This years memorial events for the Great East Japan Earthquake have been canceled one after another due to the spread of the COVID-19.
Even in Iwate, the only prefecture in the country that has so far had no cases of infection, most events around the Golden Week holidays in May were canceled. Organizers are now worried that the pandemic may have a lasting impact on holding disaster-related events next year, when it observes the 10th anniversary of the deadly March 11 quake and tsunami, as operations of nonprofit organizations supporting victims are having trouble continuing their activities.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: From June 1 to 18, Fukuoka Prefecture has requested residents, except in Kitakyushu City, to "carefully consider holding" entertainment festivals where it is difficult to manage the number of participants.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
Fukuoka Prefecture announced that except in Kitakyushu City, outdoor events of less than 200 people can be held from June 1
until June 18. Sufficient social distancing of 2 metres should occur as much as possible.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced that entertainment events such as sports which requires participants to travel nationwide cannot be held from June 1 to 18.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on May 29 that except in Kitakyushu City, indoor events of up to 100 people can be held from June 1 until June 18.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced from June 1 to 18 that except in Kitakyushu City that local entertainment events can be held if the number of participants can be determined and if there are not people coming "from nationwide or across a wide area".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 06-01-20, the Hiroshima Peace Memorial in Japan is set to reopen to the public, though at a limited number of visitors, after it was closed on February 1 due to the coronavirus pandemic.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On April 7, 2020, the Zamami Yacht Race executive committee of the island of Zamami (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has announced the cancellation of the 43th Zamami Yacht Race, scheduled to be held on June 2, 2020, "to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On June 2, 2020, the Tarama Island Round Marathon Race Executive Committee (Tarama Island, Miyako, Okinawa, Japan) decided to cancel the 23rd Tarama Island Round Marathon Race, scheduled to take place on November 21, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 5, 2020, it was announced that the 2020's edition of the "Fuji Rock Festival", scheduled to be held in Niigata Prefecture (Japan) from August 21 until August 23, 2020 will be postponed to August 2021.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Five public beaches in Ishinomaki, Miyagi Prefecture, including two which had planned to resume operation for the first time in a decade since they were swept away by the March 2011 earthquake-triggered tsunami, will not open this summer to help prevent the spread of coronavirus.
The city office plans to put up signs asking visitors to refrain from using the beaches.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: After being closed from April 12 until June 15 due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Oshimenawa Creative Museum in Shimane (Japan) will be reopened on June 16.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 19, the Hiroshima Research Institute in Japan reopened based on Hiroshima's coping policy to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 19, 2020, the Japan Sport Association, the Japanese Para-Sports Association, the Kagoshima prefectural government and the Japan Sports Agency "decided to put off the 75th National Sports Festival, originally slated for October in Kagoshima Prefecture, marking the first postponement of the annual event that began in 1946. A similar decision was made for the 20th annual national para-sports festival, originally set to start also in the southwestern prefecture following the National Sports Festival." "The two events usually bring together about 800,000 people, including spectators, in total."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From June 19, Fukuoka Prefecture has extended the request for residents "carefully consider holding" entertainment festivals where it is difficult to manage the number of participants. Furthermore, the policy now applies to Kitakyushu City, who were previously excluded. UPDATE: Original policy applied until June 18 and applied to all of Fukuoka Prefecture except Kitakyushu City. But now policy has been extended indefinitely from June 19 and applies to Kitakyushu City as well.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on June 19 that outdoor events such concerts and exhibitions can now have 1,000 spectators if "sufficient distance is secured between the spectator seats" (2 metres if possible). Furthermore, the policy applies to all of Fukuoka Prefecture, including Kitakyushu City, who were previously excluded. UPDATE: Original policy had outdoor events restricted to 200 people and applied to Fukuoka Prefecture except Kitakyushu City. From June 19, policy has been relaxed so that it 1,000 spectators are allowed, including in Kitakyushu City.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on June 19 that entertainment events such as professional sports which requires participants to travel nationwide can be "held without spectators". Furthermore, these events can also be held in Kitakyushu City, which was previously excluded. UPDATE: Originally, entertainment events requiring nationwide movement could not be held, but can now be held with spectators from June 19. Furthermore, the policy applies to all of Fukuoka Prefecture including Kitakyushu City (which was previously excluded).
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on June 19 that indoor "games should be held in a stadium accepting 1,000 spectators at maximum", but that admission should only be half of its capacity. Furthermore, the policy now extends to all of Fukuoka Prefecture, including the previously excluded Kitakyushu City. UPDATE: Original policy applied to Fukuoka Prefecture (except Kitakyushu City) and restricted indoor events to up to 100 people. But from June 19, now it applies to all Fukuoka Prefecture and indoor events can hold more people.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: From June 19, Fukuoka Prefecture has extended the request for local entertainment events to be held only if the number of participants can be determined and if there are not people coming "from nationwide or across a wide area". Furthermore, the policy now applies to Kitakyushu City as well, who were previously excluded. UPDATE: Original policy set to last until June 18 and extended to Fukuoka Prefecture except Kitakyushu City. But now, the policy has been extended indefinitely and applies to Kitakyushu City as well.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On June 24, the Hiroshima prefecture (Japan) released the following conditions of holding an event, which will remain in effect until July 9:

"If it is indoors, the number of participants should be less than 1,000 and less than half of the capacity.
If it is outdoors, 1,000 people or less and a sufficient distance between people (2m as much as possible)
Regarding the holding of large-scale events nationwide, we ask the organizer to take careful measures to cancel or postpone it if the risk assessment cannot be completed."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On April 7, 2020, the Sabani Sailing Race executive committee of the island of Zamami (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has announced the cancellation of the 9th Marylin Cup, scheduled to be held on June 27, 2020, "to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The "Chiyuko Mizutani Thank You Concert 2020" in Shimane (Japan), which was scheduled to be held in Grantois on Sunday, June 28, was postponed to October 18 to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infectious disease.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, 2020, the Sabani Sailing Race executive committee of the island of Zamami (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has announced the cancellation of the 21st Sabani Sailing Race, scheduled to be held on June 28, 2020, "to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: As announced on May 20, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) cancelled its 2020 tourism campaign "Okayama Fruit Time", held annually from July to October.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: For the "Odds-Adventures of Edo Paintings" exhibition that is being held at the Prefectural Museum of Art in the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) from July 7th, "it is possible to avoid the "three denseness" in the exhibition room and to have everyone watch in peace. We have introduced a capacity system (60 people every 30 minutes)."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on July 10 that "music concerts, exhibitions, and pro-sport events" can now host "up to 5,000 people" at outdoor venues. UPDATE: Original policy allowed outdoor events of up to 200 people, which was updated to 1000 people on June 19, which has now been updated to 5000 people on July 10.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced from July 10 that "music concerts, exhibitions, and pro-sport events can now host up to 5,000 people at indoor" venues. If events have 1,000 or more people, organizers are "asked to consult the prefecture's task team". UPDATE: Original policy said indoor events of up to 100 people can be held, then updated to 1,000 people from June 19. Now from July 10, indoor events of up to 5,000 people can be held.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On the 13 July 2020, the Osaka prefectural government asked its residents not to visit nightlife entertainment establishments with poor measures against the new coronavirus. This request will be effective until 31 July 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On July 14, 2020, Miyakojima (Okinawa, Japan) announced the cancellation of the annual gathering to show respect for the aged (<U+656C><U+8001><U+4F1A>, keirokai in Japanese), scheduled for September 2020, in order to reduce the risk of infection.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On July 17, the governor of the Yamaguchi Prefecture issued a declaration setting guidelines for mass gatherings. 

"The scale is less than 5,000 people both indoors and outdoors. When indoors, the number of participants is less than half of the capacity, and when outdoors, there is a sufficient distance between people. please. Also, if you plan to hold an event that involves the movement of people nationwide or an event that involves more than 1,000 participants, please consult the prefecture in advance."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On July 26, 2020, the Okinawa Bullfighting Association (Uruma City, Okinawa, Japan) announced the decision "to cancel the '11th All-Okinawa Summer Bullfighting Festival' set to take place at the Ishikawa Dome in Uruma in August."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on July 30 for residents to "refrain from dining and going out for drinks in large groups".
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On July 31, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, asked to consider cancelling, postponing or reducing the scale of events and to take sufficient measures against infection when holding events from August 1, 2020 until August 15, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, asked to consider holding events online, reducing their scale, and cancel events, when sufficient measures against infection cannot be taken, until August 29, 2020. UPDATE: Extended until August 29
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 4, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that the "imperial garden party planned for the fall has been canceled to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus amid growing concern over a resurgence of infections." "Around 2,000 guests usually attend the parties at the Akasaka Imperial Gardens in Tokyo, where the emperor and empress greet and converse with those who have made notable constructions to the worlds of culture, sports and science."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 5, 2020, Itoman (Okinawa Island, Okinawa, Japan) announced the cancellation of the annual gathering to show respect for the aged (<U+656C><U+8001><U+4F1A>, keirokai in Japanese), scheduled for October 2020, in order to reduce the risk of infection.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Aichi (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, called "on the public to not have meals or parties in a group of five or more."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period." "Regarding trips to hometowns, Abe also called on people to refrain from events at high risks of infection, such as dining in a large group, and take extra care to protect elderly people from the virus."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On 05-29-20, the Hiroshima Municipal Government (Japan) announced that it will downsize this years peace memorial ceremony for the atomic bombing due to the coronavirus outbreak. Rather than being open to general participants, only atomic bomb survivors and relatives of the victims will be invited.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 6, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) celebrated the 75th anniversary of the nuclear assault at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park. The coronavirus forced them to curtail the events, moving conferences on nuclear disarmament online, canceling or postponing related meetings and reducing the number of attendees to around 800, one-tenth of the turnout during a normal year.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 12, 2020, Miyakojima (Okinawa, Japan) announced the cancellation of the annual summer children's ecotour, scheduled for August 21, 2020, in order to reduce the risk of infection.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked to reduce gatherings to a small number of people and, when gathering, to take preventive infection measures, such as not sitting face-to-face.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On July 13, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that it is cancelling the "human rights contact festival" scheduled on August 22 at Hagi-shi to prevent the spread of the coronavirus infection.

description:
As announced on April 27 by the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan), public transport operators are taking the following preventive measures against infectious diseases.

"As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are encouraging airport staff to wear masks and install disinfectant solutions at airport entrances to encourage airport users to disinfect their hands.
In addition, each airline also implements measures such as wearing masks and gloves for flight attendants and ground personnel, disinfecting cabins in the cabin, and circulating air.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, bus crews wear masks to operate and guide passengers. In addition, we are implementing disinfection and ventilation inside the vehicle, as well as restrictions on the use of buses in the front row in order to keep the distance between the driver and the driver.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as employee wearing masks and installing disinfectant.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as wearing masks for employees and arousing and disinfecting trains."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "asked prefectures on the special alert to continue to keep measures in place. The government is to analyze in detail the effects of calls by central and local governments to refrain from nonessential outings and hometown visits during the spring break."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: On May 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on residents of 13 prefectures where special alert for the novel coronavirus is requested to continue efforts to reduce interpersonal contact by 80 pct. The government is concerned about the possibility of citizens in the 13 prefectures - Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa, Saitama, Osaka, Hyogo, Fukuoka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi and Kyoto - relaxing their social distancing efforts."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
Starting from May 14, 2020, Sendai city gave rules to customers in restaurants. 
 The tables should be separated by partitions to prevent splash infection, or side-by-side with a space of at least 2m (at least 1m).
Arrange the layout so that you can sit in, and open an appropriate space so that the counter seats do not stick together.
 Avoid direct layout, or devise a partition (such as acrylic plate) on the table.
 If you want to meet face-to-face with a small number of family members and caregivers, such as the elderly, infants and people with disabilities, this may be possible, but with other groups
Avoid sharing seats.
 To ensure safety between groups, keep at least 2m (at least 1m) away from other groups and keep conversations modest.
And consider recommending listening to BGM.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On May 16, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on people to stay alert against the new coronavirus." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi stated that "carelessness can lead to a new wave of the outbreak, urging people not to relax efforts to contain the virus," calling on "residents of the 39 prefectures to continue containment efforts while resuming economic activities gradually. For residents of the eight prefectures where the state of emergency is still in place, Nishimura underlined the need for continued efforts to reduce contact by 80 pct."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On May 17, 2020, the Government of Japan "called for continued voluntary restrictions by residents of the eight prefectures where its coronavirus state of emergency remains in effect" (Hokkaido, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo). "Economic and fiscal policy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura called for these residents' continued cooperation to ensure that the state of emergency is lifted within this month. "A second wave of infections could come. People should continue voluntary restrictions without becoming relaxed about them," Nishimura said."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: From June 1, 2020, Japan's carrier All Nippon Airways "will make it mandatory for passengers to wear a mask aboard planes and at the airport." "[E]veryone will be required to wear a mask at all times on planes and at the airport, including at security checkpoints and boarding gates. The airline says it may deny boarding to people not wearing a mask or showing symptoms of illness, including fever. Exceptions will be made for small children and certain particular cases."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
